p.s: The novel The Tortilla Curtain, written by T. C. Boyle and released around 1990, deals with America's immigration problem and the xenophobia that comes with it.

The given excerpt, Part Two, Chapterpart two, chapter 6, is about Delaney, a self-claimed environmental humanist, suspecting a mexicanMexican, called José Navidad, for wanting to rob the Cherrystones' house.

Delaney Mossbacher is one of the main-charactersmain characters in the novel, who is not a racist at first, but slowly develops hatred and fear against the illegal mexicanMexican immigrants after both of his dogs got eaten by a coyote and his car gettinggot stolen.
José Navidad is a side-characterside character who has had a few encounters with Delaney already, none of those being positive encounters.
He has been spotted in Topanga Canyon before, and Delaney suspected him for being the one who was littering in the canyon.
Aside from that, José also holds a criminal record in which he has raped América, the pregnant wife of Candido, the other protagonist, and threatened Kyra, Delaney's wife, as well.

In this chapter, Delaney sees José near the Cherrystone'sCherrystones' residence, a wealtywealthy family who lives in the same residential area as Delaney: Arroyo Blanco, and due to his paranoid behaviour, he immediately comes to the conclusion that José must be here to rob them, since the Cherrystones are currently away.
Delaney confronts José and asks him passive agressive what he is doing there, but José did not give much of a reaction.
That is until Delaney grabs his forearm.
He releases himself from his grip and spits between Delaney's feet, to which Delaney proceeded to threaten him by calling the police.
To his surprise, the man took out a few fliersflyers and handed one to Delaney.
José spits on him again and leaves.

The chapter ends with Delaney reading what is on the flierflyer, and it is a message from Jack Jardine, the Arroyo Blanco Estates Property Owners Association boss, who is calling on a town hall meeting about building a gate around Arroyo Blanco, to protect themselves from the wild, but also the mexicansMexicans.
